description: From Middle English [Term?], from past participle of Old French referer (“to relate, to refer”), from Latin referre (“to carry back, to report, to notify”); as if refer +‎ -ee, that is, the person to whom something is referred for consideration.

entries.meaning: (sports) An umpire or judge; an official who makes sure the rules are followed during a game.
examples: The referee kicked Jim out of the game for fighting.

entries.meaning: A person who settles a dispute.
(UK) A person who writes a letter of reference or provides a reference by phone call for someone. US English: reference.
examples: Your application, along with letters from three referees, should be received by January 31.

entries.meaning: An expert who judges the manuscript of an article or book to decide if it should be published.

verbs.description: referee (third-person singular simple present referees, present participle refereeing, simple past and past participle refereed)

examples: He has to referee three hockey games this weekend.
She has to finish refereeing an article for Nature.
